comments:
when I try to launch eclipse.exe I get an error message and then it doesn't 
start.  The exception in the log file is: "...RuntimeException: No application 
id has been found..." The full message is below.  

!SESSION Jun 27, 2004 03:04:57.605 ---------------------------------------------
eclipse.buildId=I200406192000
java.version=1.4.2_04
java.vendor=Sun Microsystems Inc.
BootLoader constants: OS=win32, ARCH=x86, WS=win32, NL=en_US

!ENTRY org.eclipse.osgi Jun 27, 2004 03:04:57.605
!MESSAGE Application error
!STACK 1
java.lang.RuntimeException: No application id has been found.
	at org.eclipse.core.internal.runtime.PlatformActivator$1.run
(PlatformActivator.java:313)
	at org.eclipse.core.runtime.adaptor.EclipseStarter.run
(EclipseStarter.java:272)
	at org.eclipse.core.runtime.adaptor.EclipseStarter.run
(EclipseStarter.java:128)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke
(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:39)
	at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke
(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:25)
	at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:324)
	at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.basicRun(Main.java:186)
	at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.run(Main.java:647)
	at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.main(Main.java:631)

I believe this is really related to the RCP SDK as I see the this exact message
after simply downloading the RCP SDK, unzipping it, and launching eclipse.exe on
Windows XP.  Eclipse RCP SDK version is 3.0 final.
*** Bug 68728 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

As Todd mentions, this is the message that you will get if you try and start up
the Eclipse RCP. The RCP is intended as a framework and does not include an
application. Please download the SDK.

I'm getting this error message using eclipse-SDK-3.0-linux-gtk.zip. I've just
checked the MD5 sum to make sure I'm using the correct download archive.

I don't think this one is the RCP SDK, or is it?

That file should be the full SDK. The easiest way to check is to look in the
"eclipse/plugins" directory. In the RCP SDK there are substantially fewer plugins.

Also, did you unzip the new file over-top the old install or first remove the
old install (or install to a new dir)?

I see 83 plugin subdirectories in plugins/, so I really think this is the normal
SDK.

As for the installation, I did a completely fresh install, with no plugins at
all. I was trying to use my old workspace from 3.0 RC3, though.

are you running some sort of shared install where you have a config directory 
local to your user (you are on linux right?)?  If so, go in there and rename 
the config.ini file.  (actually, unless you have some dear preferences, I would 
just rename the whole directory).  

Note also that the original report was not on 3.0.  The build date was 06/19.  
3.0 is 06/25

Actually, I seem to have two config.ini files:

- .eclipse/.config/config.ini
- .eclipse/configuration/config.ini

Both are the same (content-wise) and look mostly empty. I'm attaching a copy so
you can have a look.

Please advise if those are the files you want me to rename, and if so, which one
to rename.

looks old.  also looks like it is not the problem.  the .config dir can be 
deleted.  It is very obsolete.  
Actually, at this point I would recommend trying to delete (rename) the entire 
configuration dir as well.  A number of things have changed over the course of 
3.0 development (and some very recently).

Whoa, I mean... Can that really be the only cure? Like I've said, I've used that
workspace and configuration successfully with 3.0 RC3, so I'm kind of surprised
that it no longer works with 3.0 final. Of course I don't want to lose all my
settings, too.

did it work?

you won't lose all your settings.   Most of them are in your workspace.  A few 
are in the config area.  If it turns out to be really problematic, some 
skillfull directory copying may solve the problem for you.

This is not a normal situation and yes, somethings did change right at the 
end.  We have not heard of problems in this transition from other people on the 
team so it may be something unique to your setup.

I haven't tried yet since that is on my work machine, and I'm at home now again.
I will try the steps you mentioned tomorrow morning.

DJ Houghton  wrote:
>As Todd mentions, this is the message 
>that you will get if you try and start up
>the Eclipse RCP. The RCP is intended as 
>a framework and does not include an
>application. Please download the SDK.

Actually, I would expect this behavior from the download marked as the RCP
Binary distribution, but my expectations for something labeled RCP SDK is that
it is a runnable SDK for building RCP applications.  Is that not correct? 
Because as it is, the SDK does not run out of the box.  If it's not intended to,
is the only difference between the RCP binary and SDK downloads the inclusion of
source code?

You are correct, the only difference between the RCP binary and SDK drops is the
inclusion of source.

There is a good description under the RCP binary download on the downloads page.
It states that it is a target for RCP apps.

Most people will end up using the general Eclipse SDK for development and set
their target platform to be an install of the RCP download.

In following up to comment #12 and comment #13, I've now deleted
~/.eclipse/.config and ~/.eclipse/configuration, and it seems to be working
again now. Thanks for your help.

traces.message: No application id has been found.
